results.title: Threats and Fear Cause Afghan Women’s Protections to Vanish Overnight
results.abstract: As the Taliban advanced, safe houses for women closed, and the staff sheltered girls at home as relatives released from prison threatened to kill them.

results.title: Beavers Re-emerge in Scotland, Drawing Ire of Farmers
results.abstract: Building dams that flood land, the beavers have infuriated farmers. Some have obtained permits to kill the animals — setting off outrage among conservationists.

results.title: Indian vs. Black: Vigilante Killings Upend a South African Town
results.abstract: As rioting and looting swept the country this summer, Indians in the suburb of Phoenix set up roadblocks to police their streets. Dozens of Black people passing through wound up dead.
results.byline: By John Eligon and Zanele Mji

multimedia.caption: Riled up by videos, WhatsApp messages and the sight of Black residents from neighboring communities charging into their town, Phoenix residents took to the streets to set up roadblocks.
multimedia.copyright: João Silva/The New York Times

results.title: As Kashmir Crackdown Endures, Poets Stifle Their Verses
results.abstract: Harsh measures against dissent have trickled down to practitioners of the region’s poetic traditions, with many saying they have been told to stop.

multimedia.caption: Ghulam Mohammad Bhat, who writes under the pen name Madhosh Balhami, reads and composes poetry in secret in Kashmir, sometimes by the banks of the Jhelum River.

results.title: After Stabbing Attack, New Zealand Examines Its Antiterrorism Efforts
results.abstract: A man who wounded seven people in a supermarket had been under surveillance for months. Officials say a loophole in the country’s laws needs to be closed.

results.title: An Economic Lifeline in South America, the Paraná River, Is Shriveling
results.abstract: The continent’s second-largest river is drying up amid the biggest drought in 70 years, upending ecosystems, trade and livelihoods.
results.byline: By Daniel Politi and Sebastián López Brach

multimedia.caption: Two old cement ships were uncovered as the Paraná River receded last month.

results.title: Married Kremlin Spies, a Shadowy Mission to Moscow and Unrest in Catalonia
results.abstract: Intelligence files suggest an aide to a top Catalan separatist sought help from Russia in the struggle to break with Spain. A fierce new protest group emerged shortly afterward.
results.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and José Bautista

multimedia.caption: A protest in support of the Catalan independence referendum in Barcelona, in 2017. Spain declared the vote illegal and jailed several of the politicians who called it.

results.title: Waste From Mine in Angola Kills 12 Downstream in Congo, Minister Says
results.abstract: Toxic metals from Angola’s largest diamond mine spilled into the Kasai River in July, sickening thousands and causing an “environmental catastrophe,” researchers said.
results.byline: By Gilberto Neto and Ruth Maclean

results.title: New Zealand Police Kill ‘Extremist’ Who Stabbed 6 in ISIS-Inspired Attack
results.abstract: The man was under surveillance when he injured six people at a West Auckland supermarket on Friday, officials said. The prime minister called it a “terrorist attack.”

multimedia.caption: Supermarket staff and police officers after a man walked in, grabbed a knife off the shelf and stabbed several people in West Auckland, New Zealand, on Friday.

results.title: The W.H.O. lists Mu as a ‘variant of interest.’
results.abstract: The variant, first identified in Colombia, has characteristics that suggest it might be able to evade antibodies from vaccination or infection.

multimedia.caption: A Covid-19 patient in Bogota, Colombia, in May. The World Health Organization said the Mu variant, responsible for many cases in Colombia, has the potential to evade immunity provided by vaccines.
multimedia.copyright: Vanessa Jimenez/AFP — Getty Images

results.title: Restoration of Kabul’s Closed Airport Begins as Some Afghan Aid Resumes
results.abstract: Despite the Taliban’s effort to project themselves as responsible stewards after seizing power, there was still no word on when a new government would be announced.
results.byline: By Jim Huylebroek, Fahim Abed, Christina Goldbaum and Rick Gladstone

results.title: King County in Washington, home to Seattle, will require masks at large outdoor events.
results.abstract: The mandate, which begins Tuesday, will require masks be worn at outdoor events that attract more than 500 people.

results.title: How Will the Taliban Govern? A History of Rebel Rule Offers Clues.
results.abstract: Insurgents who seize power tend to be authoritarian but pragmatic, desperate for legitimacy and ruthless toward classes they see as hostile.

results.title: Danish Official Faces Impeachment Trial Over Migration Policy Separating Couples
results.abstract: Inger Stojberg, who presided over tough anti-immigrant policies when her party was in charge, is being tried on charges of illegally separating couples who sought asylum.
results.byline: By Isabella Kwai and Jasmina Nielsen
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Inger Stojberg, Denmark’s former immigration minister, speaking in Copenhagen on Thursday.

results.title: The French Left Is in Disarray, but Here Comes Anne Hidalgo
results.abstract: The charismatic and divisive socialist mayor of Paris is eyeing an office that has been occupied by eight male presidents over six decades.

multimedia.caption: Anne Hidalgo, the socialist mayor of Paris, center, attended a Socialist Party event last week in Blois, France.
